description: From em- (prefix meaning ‘on, onto; covered’) +‎ panoply (“complete set of armour”); panoply is derived from Ancient Greek πᾰνοπλῐ́ᾱ (panoplíā, “suit of armour”), from πάνοπλος (pánoplos, “in full armour”) (from παν- (pan-, prefix meaning ‘all, every’) + ὅπλον (hóplon, “armour; arms, weapons”)) + -ῐ́ᾱ (-íā, suffix forming feminine abstract nouns).

verbs.description: empanoply (third-person singular simple present empanoplies, present participle empanoplying, simple past and past participle empanoplied)

entries.meaning: (transitive, Britain, military, historical, also figuratively) To dress in a full suit of armour; to panoply.
